questions.question_text:
A customer built a computer with the following specifications:
✑ Single hexa-core processor
✑ 8GB DDR4 memory
✑ 256GB SSD drive
✑ Built-in graphics card
✑ 32-bit Windows OS
✑ Audio editing software
The computer seems to be working, but the OS reports only 3.5GB of RAM is available. Which of the following would correct the issue?

discussion.content: Yes, it is correct because 32-bit Windows OS can only hold upto 4 GB of RAM.
The question should really be “Which of the following upgrades would correct the issue?”

comments.content: The maximum RAM for a 32-bit Windows OS is 4GB, so it is totally useless to put more RAM into the pc

discussion.content: I'M still confused why is it not upgrade the ram to 16 gb ddr4

NTFS - used for Windows (incorrect)
Ext 4 - native to Linux 
HFS - applies to apple (incorrect)
FAT32 - used mainly for USBs but can be used for either (second best option)

questions.question_text: A customer has a Linux desktop and is installing a 3TB HDD. The customer wants to use only half of its capacity right now, but would like to be able to increase the size of the partition at a later date. Which of the following filesystem types would the customer's drive require?

choices.C: Restore the computer to the previous checkpoint
choices.A: Disconnect the device from the network

comments.content: Would the "has been infected with malware" be considered 'Step 1- Identify malware' and be done already? If so would the answer be instead 2, 4 and 5?
This is a very fair point...so the answer could be ADG in that case. Tricky question!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABD
1.Identify and research malware symptoms. ...
2. Quarantine the infected systems. ...
3. Disable System Restore (in Windows). ...
4. Remediate the infected systems. ...
5. Schedule scans and run updates. ...
6. Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows). ...
7.Educate the end user.

Just learn these steps ;)

• A. Disconnect the device from the network – 2nd step. It could use a cellular network or it still could be connected to the WiFi. Don’t assume that the laptop isn’t connected to the network.
• B. Identify and research the symptoms – 1st step. This has been already done. Read the question.
• C. Restore the computer to the previous checkpoint – checkpoint isn’t a restore point. It could be the restore point, but the restore point isn’t enabled by default.
• D. Scan and use removal techniques – 4th step
• E. Create a restore point – 6th step
• F. Educate the end user – last 7th step
• G. Schedule scans and run updates – 5th step

The answers are A, D and G
CAN THE ANSWER BE BDA? JUST WONDERING

questions.question_text: A technician receives the Chief Executive Officer's (CEO's) Windows 10 laptop, which has been infected with malware. The technician wants to make sure best practices are followed for troubleshooting and remediating the malware. Which of the following best practices should the technician perform FIRST in this scenario? (Choose three.)

While preparing a computer that will be issued to a new user, the technician discovers the computer's former user configured a supervisor password in the BIOS.
Which of the following can the technician do to allow the password to be removed?

choices.A: Reimage the machine from a network share
choices.D: Use the BIOS user password to reset the supervisor password
choices.C: Remove and then replace the CMOS battery
choices.B: Change the boot order and boot to an external drive

discussion.content: Better way to ask this is “what should the technician try FIRST” as it is no longer guaranteed to work. Some manufacturers have patched the “just remove the battery” security flaw and now a tech could be required to use hardware hacks, third party workarounds or go to the manufacturer for a Master Unlock service to remove that unknown password.

comments.content: C is correct to try FIRST

discussion.content: You can still try removing the CMOS battery and see if it works and if not I guess you can go from there. Try the easy way first.

comments.content: No, not guaranteed on modern hardware.

discussion.content: In the real world, this will not work anymore.. You prolly need to set a jumper to delete a password from the bios.

comments.content: CompTIA is not in the real world...FYI
exactly , this isnt the real world this is comptiaWorld.

questions.question_text: Which of the following wireless security protocols supports the use of a 40-bit encryption key?

discussion.content: WEP encryption uses a standard 40-bit encryption to scramble data packets.
